Substeps.SubstepString: Identify the target port as port 11111
Recognize the presence of an SQL Injection vulnerability

Steps.StepString: Confronted with stability issues with multiple users trying to attack using sqlmap simultaneously

Substeps.SubstepString: Realize the cause of stability issues is multiple users attacking simultaneously with sqlmap

Steps.StepString: Managed to extract a very long alphanumeric password from the database

Substeps.SubstepString: Successfully extract a password from the database
Observe the extracted password is very long and alphanumeric

Steps.StepString: Encountered an obstacle where the password was longer than the max character limit allowed by the login page

Substeps.SubstepString: Face an obstacle due to the password length exceeding the character limit of the login page

Steps.StepString: Bypassed the character limit issue by passing the password with Burp Suite

Substeps.SubstepString: Discover a method to bypass the character limit issue
Use Burp Suite to pass the password despite the character limit

Steps.StepString: Retrieved a link leading to flag.png file after passing the password
Identified in hindsight an alternate solution to bypass the login via the username field using SQL injection

Substeps.SubstepString: Recognize an alternative method to bypass the login via the username field
Realize the alternative method involves using SQL injection

Steps.StepString: Identified an alternative approach to bypass authentication using the password field

Substeps.SubstepString: Discover an alternative approach to bypass authentication
Identify the password field as the entry point for bypassing authentication

Steps.StepString: Missed the potential for using an SQL injection into the password field as an authentication bypass.

Substeps.SubstepString: Fail to recognize the potential for using an SQL injection into the password field as an authentication bypass
